skill.name: create-issue
skill.description: Create an issue in GitHub or Jira. Automatically detects if GitHub issues are enabled; if so creates a GitHub issue, otherwise creates a Jira issue.
skill.summary: Create GitHub or Jira issues automatically. Detects issue tracker type and uses appropriate CLI tools.
skill.author: Cloud-Officer

security_audit.summary: This skill creates issues in GitHub or Jira using standard CLI tools. All static findings are false positives: pattern matching incorrectly flagged GitHub URLs as C2 indicators and git-related terms as cryptographic algorithms. The skill uses legitimate gh and jira CLI commands for issue creation - this is standard developer tooling behavior.

content.value_statement: Developers spend valuable time manually creating issues across different trackers. This skill automates issue creation by detecting whether GitHub issues are enabled and using the appropriate CLI tool with proper templates.
actual_capabilities: Detects if GitHub issues are enabled for a repository
Creates GitHub issues using the gh CLI tool
Creates Jira issues using the jira CLI tool
Uses appropriate templates for Task, Bug, or Story issue types
Maps severity levels to Jira priorities (Critical, High, Medium, Low, Info)
Cleans up temporary files after issue creation
limitations: Requires gh CLI installed and authenticated for GitHub issues
Requires jira CLI installed and configured for Jira issues
Does not support creating issues without CLI tools
Cannot create issues on trackers other than GitHub or Jira

use_cases.title: Quick Bug Reporting
use_cases.description: Rapidly document bugs with structured templates including environment details, reproduction steps, and impact assessment.

use_cases.title: Task Definition for Sprints
use_cases.description: Create well-structured user stories with acceptance criteria, dependencies, and technical details for sprint planning.

use_cases.title: Technical Task Documentation
use_cases.description: Document technical tasks with security considerations, testing strategies, and implementation details.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Bug Report
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a bug issue for this problem: [describe the bug]. The environment is [environment details]. The expected behavior is [what should happen].
prompt_templates.scenario: Quickly log a bug with essential details

prompt_templates.title: Feature Request
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a user story for: As a [user type], I want to [goal] so that [benefit]. Include acceptance criteria and technical notes.
prompt_templates.scenario: Formalizing feature requests for sprint planning

prompt_templates.title: Technical Task
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a technical task for [description]. Include security impact assessment, testing strategy, and technical implementation details.
prompt_templates.scenario: Documenting technical work with full context

prompt_templates.title: Custom Issue
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a [Task|Bug|Story] issue with title: [title] and body: [detailed description]. Assign to [username] if specified. Priority: [level].
prompt_templates.scenario: Full control over all issue parameters

output_examples.input: Create a bug issue: The login button does not respond when clicked in production environment.
output_examples.output: GitHub issue created successfully: #123 - Login button not responding

output_examples.input: Create a user story for the new dashboard feature
output_examples.output: Jira issue created: [repo-name] User story: Dashboard feature with detailed template

best_practices: Provide complete context: environment details, steps to reproduce, and expected behavior for bug reports
Use appropriate issue types (Task, Bug, Story) to match your project tracking workflow
Include security considerations in technical tasks to ensure compliance requirements are met
anti_patterns: Creating issues without descriptions or with vague content that lacks actionable detail
Using Jira when GitHub issues are enabled instead of letting the skill auto-detect
Skipping template sections instead of marking them as N/A when not applicable

faq.question: What happens if both GitHub and Jira are configured?
faq.answer: The skill checks if GitHub issues are enabled first. If enabled, it uses GitHub. Otherwise, it defaults to Jira.

faq.question: Do I need to install both gh and jira CLI tools?
faq.answer: You only need the CLI tool for the tracker you use. The skill will detect which one to use based on your repository configuration.

faq.question: Can I create issues on self-hosted GitHub Enterprise?
faq.answer: Yes, as long as gh CLI is configured to authenticate with your GitHub Enterprise instance.

faq.question: How are priorities mapped between severity and Jira?
faq.answer: Critical maps to Blocker, High to Critical, Medium to Major, and Low/Info to Minor.

faq.question: What if the gh or jira command hangs?
faq.answer: The skill sets a 15-second timeout for Jira commands. If a command appears malformed or hangs, it will time out.

faq.question: Where are temporary files created?
faq.answer: A temporary file named issue-body.md is created in the working directory and automatically deleted after the issue is created.
